body: Of observation lying on the groundand preening, dancing on the basepaths,They tear apart the mist, it is as though,Brush the lone giant in that somber pall.Suddenly, in a savage, dreadful bend,But what I am looking at is hardened snow,At San Biagio, in the most intense roomAnd he is swathed in ever-petrified dread;As it sits there like an eventualThe edge of that other square cut from the rightLife, or only joy, that stands outPartly stone, partly the absence of stone,Late February, and the air's so balmySits at the limit of a kind of worldIt's snowing, it's returning to a townBut snow has gathered there, has piled up,Point, after all, when finally one reachesThat only you and I can know. Les deuxshaded by live oaks and bottlebrush trees
